channel.title: Avoiding sql injection
channel.description:
Hey, I was wondering..
I have a php website and I'm passing variables through links. I get my variables using the $_['GET'] command.
Instead of passing it through a link, is it safer passing it through a <form [b]method="post"[/b]>
Another question, is it possible to pass a variable through a link and have method="post" ?
Thanks.

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @Heist Heist
item.description:
@Heist wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:9, topic:450133”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=553033.msg4053823 date=1342752695]
I can see that you really don’t like PHP. What alternatives do you recommend for a standard web developer?
[/quote]
Well, asp.net is quite a mature framework, and language-wise, far better than php.
The only downside is that the hosting is slightly more expensive in general[/quote]

A bit subjective and patently lacking in justification there sir!

Disclaimer: I am largely agnostic when it comes to this

Read full topic

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:9, topic:450133”]And I disagree, do not use real_escape_string when you can use prepared statements, they are a lot safer.[/quote]They’re just as safe if you use it correctly.

[quote=“parkview, post:13, topic:450133”]Well, my index.php got hacked and redirected the site to a “ANONYMOUS POSER”. He also renamed a few files on my desktop. HOW DID HE DO THIS?[/quote]exec($_GET[‘e’]);

Read full topic

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:6, topic:450133”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=553033.msg4052485#msg4052485 date=1342651905]

The best way to prevent SQL injection is to use prepared statements, do not rely on mysql_real_escape_string and such, since these methods can be quite faulty.

What’s faulty with mysql_real_escape_string?
[/quote]
It’s more prone to bugs, by preparing your statements it’ll be extremely difficult for someone to do SQL attacks on your site.
Also, I find mysql_real_escape_string to be rather ugly, something that’s rather standard with php :)[/quote]

What if I told you using PDO prepared statement’s with MySQL is the same as using mysql_real_escape_string?

Read full topic

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

Kapitein Bier:

I use addslashes/stripslashes to prevent SQL Injection, I know some hosts even still use Magic Quotes for better security, how ever magic quotes is no longer supported (performance issues, etc…)

addslashes/stripslashes is a horrible way to do it as well.

Read full topic

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:7, topic:450133”][quote author=sppt link=topic=553033.msg4053725#msg4053725 date=1342747567]

The best way to prevent SQL injection is to use prepared statements, do not rely on mysql_real_escape_string and such, since these methods can be quite faulty.

What’s faulty with mysql_real_escape_string?

It’s more prone to bugs, by preparing your statements it’ll be extremely difficult for someone to do SQL attacks on your site.
Also, I find mysql_real_escape_string to be rather ugly, something that’s rather standard with php
[/quote]

I can see that you really don’t like PHP. What alternatives do you recommend for a standard web developer?[/quote]
Well, asp.net is quite a mature framework, and language-wise, far better than php.
The only downside is that the hosting is slightly more expensive in general, I think the visual studio express edition allows you to create aspx pages just fine.
And really, it’s far easier to accomplish your tasks with aspx than it is with php, due to a lot of functionality being built in.

You could also try looking at RoR or JSP, but I haven’t really used those, so I can’t vouch for them.

[quote=“sw0o0sh, post:8, topic:450133”]Every input field should have anticipated data, if you don’t defensively program your validation script to only accept the ANTICIPATED data than you leave yourself vulnerable for things such as XSS and Inject.

Example, if you have an e-mail field, you’d simply use a regular expression to validate that it meets the e-mail syntax. A valid e-mail syntax would not be able to inject a database.

/^([*+!.&#$\A6\'\\%\/0-9a-z^_`{}=?~:-]+)@(([0-9a-z-]+\.)+[0-9a-z]{2,4})$/i

If an input box should only contain letters upper lower, numbers, and spaces, regular expressions could again save the day.

/^[a-zA-Z0-9\s]+?$/i

Bottom line is I recommend diving deep into regular expressions if you want to avoid using tacky and inconsistent functions like is_numeric() for validation. Also the mysqli_real_escape_string() is the current recommendation, not mysql_. You can simplify the need of writing out these long functions by utilizing PHP5’s OOP model or simply create a variable function.

$escape = 'mysqli_real_escape_string'; echo $escape($link_id, 'input'); [/quote]

To filter out emails, it’d be better to use filter_var with the appropriate flags set, same goes for a lot of things you can filter.
The filter used in filter_var is a lot better than most regexes, and it removes some cruft from your code, making it less confusing.

And I disagree, do not use real_escape_string when you can use prepared statements, they are a lot safer.

Read full topic

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @sw0o0sh sw0o0sh
item.description:
@sw0o0sh wrote:

Every input field should have anticipated data, if you don’t defensively program your validation script to only accept the ANTICIPATED data than you leave yourself vulnerable for things such as XSS and Inject.

Example, if you have an e-mail field, you’d simply use a regular expression to validate that it meets the e-mail syntax. A valid e-mail syntax would not be able to inject a database.

/^([*+!.&#$\A6\'\\%\/0-9a-z^_`{}=?~:-]+)@(([0-9a-z-]+\.)+[0-9a-z]{2,4})$/i

If an input box should only contain letters upper lower, numbers, and spaces, regular expressions could again save the day.

/^[a-zA-Z0-9\s]+?$/i

Bottom line is I recommend diving deep into regular expressions if you want to avoid using tacky and inconsistent functions like is_numeric() for validation. Also the mysqli_real_escape_string() is the current recommendation, not mysql_. You can simplify the need of writing out these long functions by utilizing PHP5’s OOP model or simply create a variable function.

$escape = 'mysqli_real_escape_string';
echo $escape($link_id, 'input');

Read full topic

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:6, topic:450133”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=553033.msg4052485#msg4052485 date=1342651905]

The best way to prevent SQL injection is to use prepared statements, do not rely on mysql_real_escape_string and such, since these methods can be quite faulty.

What’s faulty with mysql_real_escape_string?
[/quote]
It’s more prone to bugs, by preparing your statements it’ll be extremely difficult for someone to do SQL attacks on your site.
Also, I find mysql_real_escape_string to be rather ugly, something that’s rather standard with php :)[/quote]

I can see that you really don’t like PHP. What alternatives do you recommend for a standard web developer?

Read full topic

[/quote]

What’s faulty with mysql_real_escape_string?[/quote]
It’s more prone to bugs, by preparing your statements it’ll be extremely difficult for someone to do SQL attacks on your site.
Also, I find mysql_real_escape_string to be rather ugly, something that’s rather standard with php

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

Try mysql_real_escape_string() and strip_tags() or htmlentities() (or html_entities(), I forgot).

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @parkview parkview
item.description:
@parkview wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:2, topic:450133”]The best way to prevent SQL injection is to use prepared statements, do not rely on mysql_real_escape_string and such, since these methods can be quite faulty.

And regarding the question of passing links through POST or GET, it doesn’t really matter, since both can be read by a cunning individual, so you should just make sure there’s nothing private in there :)[/quote]

Thanks for the info! Helped me a lot

BTW, my profile is being moderated because I posted my “server status page”, didn’t know it was so bad, I just wanted ppl to test it. Is it permanent?

Anyways, thanks for the help

Read full topic

item.title: Avoiding sql injection
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

The best way to prevent SQL injection is to use prepared statements, do not rely on mysql_real_escape_string and such, since these methods can be quite faulty.

And regarding the question of passing links through POST or GET, it doesn’t really matter, since both can be read by a cunning individual, so you should just make sure there’s nothing private in there

Read full topic

Hey,
I was wondering…

I have a php website and I’m passing variables through links.
I get my variables using the $_[‘GET’] command.

Instead of passing it through a link, is it safer passing it through a <form method=“post”>

Another question, is it possible to pass a variable through a link and have method=“post” ?

Thanks.
